title: Best Exercises for Torn Labrum
author: WebMD Editorial Contributor

content: The labrum is the ring of cartilage that cushions your joint socket. It acts like a rubber seal to help keep your joints in their sockets.
In your shoulder, there are two common types of labral injuries: superior labrum from anterior to posterior ( SLAP ) tears and Bankart tears, on the anterior (front) lower rim of the labrum.
Playing sports can cause a strain on your hip and shoulder labrums leading to tearing. It’s important to condition the muscles by doing strength and flexibility exercises.

content_blocks.text: The labrum is the ring of cartilage that cushions your joint socket. It acts like a rubber seal to help keep your joints in their sockets.
In your shoulder, there are two common types of labral injuries: superior labrum from anterior to posterior ( SLAP ) tears and Bankart tears, on the anterior (front) lower rim of the labrum.
Playing sports can cause a strain on your hip and shoulder labrums leading to tearing. It’s important to condition the muscles by doing strength and flexibility exercises.

sections.heading: Exercises to Help Torn Labrum
content: A torn labrum in your hip or shoulder can take up to a year to heal, so make sure you do these exercises slowly. The exercises below are meant to strengthen and stretch your muscles slowly.
Try these three exercises for torn hip labrum:
Single-Leg Deadlift
This exercise is meant to strengthen your hips and improve your coordination. You can modify this exercise by not using weights at first.
●Step 1: Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Grab a kettlebell with one hand and place the same side leg slightly behind you.

content_blocks.text: A torn labrum in your hip or shoulder can take up to a year to heal, so make sure you do these exercises slowly. The exercises below are meant to strengthen and stretch your muscles slowly.
Try these three exercises for torn hip labrum:
Single-Leg Deadlift
This exercise is meant to strengthen your hips and improve your coordination. You can modify this exercise by not using weights at first.
●Step 1: Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Grab a kettlebell with one hand and place the same side leg slightly behind you.

content: ●Step 2: Hinging from your hips, lower the kettlebell  so your chest leans toward the floor, while raising your back leg behind you until it’s parallel to the floor. If you have trouble maintaining your balance, keep your back foot on the floor.
●Step 3: Return to the starting position, and do 12-20 reps.
●Step 4: Repeat on the opposite side.
Repeat for 2-3 sets. Do this multiple times per week.
Forward and Lateral Walk
This exercise will open up your hips and build endurance.
●Step 1: Place a resistance band right above your ankles and pull your hips back into a mini squat position.
●Step 2: Staying in this position, walk forward for 15 to 20 steps. Rest for 30 seconds.
●Step 3: Returning to the mini squat position, walk laterally (to the side) for 15 to 20 steps. Rest for 30 seconds.
●Step 4: Repeat, walking laterally in the other direction.
Repeat for 2-3 sets. Do this multiple times per week.

content_blocks.text: ●Step 2: Hinging from your hips, lower the kettlebell  so your chest leans toward the floor, while raising your back leg behind you until it’s parallel to the floor. If you have trouble maintaining your balance, keep your back foot on the floor.
●Step 3: Return to the starting position, and do 12-20 reps.
●Step 4: Repeat on the opposite side.
Repeat for 2-3 sets. Do this multiple times per week.
Forward and Lateral Walk
This exercise will open up your hips and build endurance.
●Step 1: Place a resistance band right above your ankles and pull your hips back into a mini squat position.
●Step 2: Staying in this position, walk forward for 15 to 20 steps. Rest for 30 seconds.
●Step 3: Returning to the mini squat position, walk laterally (to the side) for 15 to 20 steps. Rest for 30 seconds.
●Step 4: Repeat, walking laterally in the other direction.
Repeat for 2-3 sets. Do this multiple times per week.

sections.heading: Dead Bug Exercise
content: This exercise will help strengthen your core and won’t put pressure on your hips.
●Step 1: Lie on your back with your knees in the air bent at a 90 degree angle. Extend your arms and wrists straight up in the air.
●Step 2: Tighten your core and slowly straighten and lower your right leg to the ground while reaching your left arm back overhead.
●Step 3: Return to your starting position, and repeat with the other leg.
Repeat for three sets with 12-20 repetitions. Do this multiple times per week.
Try these three exercises for torn shoulder labrum:
Cross Body Stretch
This stretch will release tension you’re holding in your shoulder. You should feel these on the outside or back of your shoulder.
●Step 1: Lay on your side with your hips and knees bent. Keep the lower shoulder and elbow at a 90 degree angle.
●Step 2: Use your other hand to grab your elbow and gently pull it across your body. Hold for 30 seconds.

content_blocks.text: This exercise will help strengthen your core and won’t put pressure on your hips.
●Step 1: Lie on your back with your knees in the air bent at a 90 degree angle. Extend your arms and wrists straight up in the air.
●Step 2: Tighten your core and slowly straighten and lower your right leg to the ground while reaching your left arm back overhead.
●Step 3: Return to your starting position, and repeat with the other leg.
Repeat for three sets with 12-20 repetitions. Do this multiple times per week.
Try these three exercises for torn shoulder labrum:
Cross Body Stretch
This stretch will release tension you’re holding in your shoulder. You should feel these on the outside or back of your shoulder.
●Step 1: Lay on your side with your hips and knees bent. Keep the lower shoulder and elbow at a 90 degree angle.
●Step 2: Use your other hand to grab your elbow and gently pull it across your body. Hold for 30 seconds.

content: ●Step 3: Repeat on the other side.
Do this stretch daily, in the morning and night.
Shoulder Flexion
This exercise will strengthen your shoulder muscles and limit stress on the torn labrum.
●Step 1: Start by lying on your side. Holding a light-weight dumbbell in your top hand, keep your elbow straight and arm parallel to the floor.
●Step 2: Raise arm up over head then back down to your side.
●Step 3: Repeat 12-20 repetitions.
●Step 4: Repeat on the other side.
Perform 2-3 sets.
Diagonal External Rotation
This exercise will help strengthen your rotator cuff and lower muscles that will support a full range of movement for your shoulder.
●Step 1: Stand upright with a resistance band in one hand. Anchor the band at waist level.
●Step 2: Start with your hand in front of your opposite front hip pocket. Keep your elbow bent at a 90 degree angle during the exercise.
●Step 3: Flex and rotate your arm back across your body. Hold for 1 to 2 seconds, then reverse the movement slowly back to the starting position.
●Step 4: Repeat 12-20 repetitions.
●Step 5: Repeat on the other side.
Repeat for three sets. Do this multiple times per week.

content_blocks.text: ●Step 3: Repeat on the other side.
Do this stretch daily, in the morning and night.

sections.heading: Safety Considerations
content: Torn labrum injuries can severely limit mobility and cause extreme pain. Be mindful of stretching and pushing yourself too much during these exercises. Stop immediately if you feel extreme pain during any of the movements.
If your pain worsens and is not relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) or ice packs, you should contact your doctor or physical therapist.

sources: BSR Physical Therapy: “Shoulder Labrum Tears: 5 Exercises Before Jumping into Surgery.”
Hospital for Special Surgery: “Shoulder Labrum Tears: An Overview.”
Medical News Today: “What is a shoulder labrum tear?”
Runner’s World: “How to Deal With an Inflamed Labrum of Hip Labral Tear.”
meta_description: Exercising can help you relieve torn labrum pain. Learn the best exercises for joints with torn labrums, how to get started, and how to maintain your range of motion.
